context: Victoria's youngest son, Leopold, was affected by <a5_0>the blood-clotting disease <a0_0><a8_0><b13_0>haemophilia B<b13_0/><a8_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/> and <a1_0><b14_0>two<b14_0/><a1_0/> of her five daughters, <a6_0><a10_0>Alice and Beatrice<a10_0/><a6_0/>, were carriers. Royal haemophiliacs descended from Victoria included her great-grandsons, <a9_0>Tsarevich Alexei of Russia, Alfonso, Prince of Asturias, and Infante Gonzalo of Spain<a9_0/>. The presence of the disease in Victoria's descendants, but not in her ancestors, led to modern speculation that her true father was not <a2_0>the <b15_0>Duke of Kent<b15_0/><a2_0/> but <a7_0>a haemophiliac<a7_0/>. There is no documentary evidence of a haemophiliac in connection with Victoria's mother, and as <a3_0><b16_0>male<b16_0/><a3_0/> carriers always suffer the disease, even if such a man had existed he would have been seriously ill. It is more likely that the mutation arose spontaneously because Victoria's father was <a4_0><b17_0>over 50<b17_0/><a4_0/> at the time of her conception and haemophilia arises more frequently in the children of <a11_0>older fathers<a11_0/>. Spontaneous mutations account for <a12_0>about a third of cases<a12_0/>.
